title: The Swinging 1960s
description: JFK, the Moon landing, civil rights, and counterculture — relive the decade that changed everything!

questions.question: In 1969, which astronaut was the first person to walk on the Moon?
questions.explanation: Neil Armstrong stepped onto the lunar surface on July 20, 1969, famously saying, 'That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind.'

questions.question: Which U.S. President was assassinated in Dallas, Texas, on November 22, 1963?
questions.explanation: JFK's assassination shocked the nation and the world. Most Americans who were alive that day vividly remember where they were when they heard the news.

questions.question: What was the name of the youth counterculture movement known for peace signs, tie-dye, and 'flower power'?
questions.explanation: The hippie movement emerged in the mid-1960s, centered in San Francisco's Haight-Ashbury district. They advocated for peace, love, and social change.

questions.question: Which civil rights leader delivered the famous 'I Have a Dream' speech in Washington, D.C., in 1963?
questions.explanation: Dr. King delivered the speech to over 250,000 people during the March on Washington. It is considered one of the greatest speeches in American history.

questions.question: What British pop group sparked 'Beatlemania' when they appeared on The Ed Sullivan Show in February 1964?
questions.explanation: An estimated 73 million Americans — about 34% of the population — watched the Beatles' first Ed Sullivan appearance on February 9, 1964.

questions.question: What 1960s fashion item, a very short skirt, was popularized by British designer Mary Quant?
questions.explanation: Mary Quant named the miniskirt after her favorite car, the Mini Cooper. It became a symbol of women's liberation and the youthful spirit of the Sixties.

questions.question: Which TV show featured a family of castaways stranded on an uncharted island?
questions.explanation: Gilligan's Island aired from 1964 to 1967. Despite only three seasons, it became a massive hit in syndication and spawned multiple TV movies.

questions.question: What toy, a fashion doll made by Mattel, was introduced in 1959 and became a cultural icon in the 1960s?
questions.explanation: Barbie was created by Ruth Handler and named after her daughter Barbara. Over one billion Barbie dolls have been sold worldwide since her debut.

questions.question: Which 1963 book by Betty Friedan is credited with sparking the second wave of the feminist movement?
questions.explanation: The Feminine Mystique challenged the idea that women could find fulfillment only through homemaking and child-rearing, inspiring millions of women to seek careers and equality.

questions.question: In 1962, which astronaut became the first American to orbit the Earth?
questions.explanation: John Glenn orbited the Earth three times aboard Friendship 7 on February 20, 1962. He later became a U.S. Senator and returned to space in 1998 at age 77.

questions.question: What board game, involving buying and selling properties, had its most popular version redesigned and widely sold in the 1960s?
questions.explanation: The Game of Life was redesigned by Reuben Klamer and Art Linkletter in 1960 for Milton Bradley's 100th anniversary, becoming one of the best-selling games of the decade.

questions.question: Which confrontation between the US and Soviet Union in October 1962 brought the world to the brink of nuclear war?
questions.explanation: For 13 days in October 1962, the Cuban Missile Crisis was the closest the Cold War came to nuclear conflict. President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev eventually reached a resolution.

questions.question: What iconic 1960s car, built by Ford, debuted in April 1964 and sold over one million units in its first two years?
questions.explanation: The Ford Mustang was unveiled at the 1964 World's Fair in New York. It was so popular that Ford dealers were overwhelmed with orders on the very first day.

questions.question: Which influential book by Rachel Carson, published in 1962, is credited with launching the modern environmental movement?
questions.explanation: Silent Spring documented the harmful effects of pesticides like DDT on wildlife and the environment. It led to a nationwide ban on DDT and the creation of the EPA.

questions.question: What landmark legislation, signed by President Johnson in 1964, outlawed discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin?
questions.explanation: The Civil Rights Act of 1964 was a monumental achievement of the civil rights movement. President Johnson used his legendary political skills to push it through Congress.
